asset.definition: An asset in ISMS is any item that has value to your organization and needs protection. Assets can be physical or logical.
types: Physical Assets: Servers, laptops, network equipment, printers, mobile devices
Logical Assets: Databases, applications, software, data files, network configurations
Information Assets: Customer data, financial records, intellectual property, employee information

context.title: ISO 27001 Context
points: Purpose: Assets are the foundation of risk assessment - you identify risks to assets
Management: Assets must be inventoried, classified, and protected according to their value
Lifecycle: Assets go through creation, use, maintenance, and disposal phases

asset.relationship: Assets belong to scopes. You create a scope first (e.g., "IT Department"), then add assets to it.
commands: create asset [name] - Create a new asset

scope.definition: A scope in ISMS (Information Security Management System) defines the boundaries of your security management system.

context.title: ISO 27001 Context
points: Purpose: Defines which parts of your organization are covered by the ISMS
Includes: Assets, processes, locations, and people within the scope
Example: "IT Department" scope might include servers, networks, and IT staff

commands: create scope [name] - Create a new scope

isms.definition: ISMS stands for Information Security Management System. It's a systematic approach to managing sensitive company information so it remains secure.

context.title: ISO 27001 Context
points: Purpose: Framework for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continuously improving information security
Components: Policies, procedures, controls, assets, risks, and people
Standards: Based on ISO 27001, ISO 22301, NIS-2 compliance requirements

elements.title: Key Elements
points: Scopes: Organizational boundaries (e.g., "IT Department", "Customer Data Processing")
Assets: Items that need protection (servers, databases, applications, data)
Controls: Security measures to mitigate risks

commands: list scopes - View your ISMS scopes
create scope [name] - Create a new scope

Scope: Defines what's included in security management
Asset: Individual items within a scope that need protection
Can be physical (servers, laptops) or logical (databases, applications)

scope_vs_asset.relationship: Scopes contain assets. You create a scope first, then add assets to it.

steps.title: Step 1: Choose a Name
steps.content: Select a name that describes the organizational boundary. Examples: "IT Department", "Customer Services", "Production Systems"

steps.title: Step 2: Use the Command
steps.content:
Type: create scope [name]
Example: create scope IT Department

steps.title: Step 3: Optional Description
steps.content: Add a description: create scope IT Department description "All IT infrastructure and staff"

scope.note: The scope will be created in your default domain. You can then add assets, controls, and other ISMS objects to it.

steps.title: Step 1: Choose a Name
steps.content:
Pick a descriptive name for your asset.
Examples: "Production Server", "Customer Database", "Employee Laptop"

steps.title: Step 2: Use the Command
steps.content:
Type: `create asset [name]`
Example: `create asset Production Server`

steps.title: Step 3: Optional Details
steps.content: Add a description: `create asset Production Server description "Main web application server"`

steps.title: Step 4: Link to a Scope (Recommended)
steps.content:
Assets should belong to scopes for proper organization.
After creating your asset, link it to a scope using the Verinice UI or API.

asset.note: Assets are the items you need to protect in your ISMS. They can be physical (servers, devices) or logical (databases, applications, data).

person.optional: Add description: create person John Smith description "IT Security Manager"
person.note: Persons represent people in your organization who have roles and responsibilities in the ISMS.

control.optional: Add description: create control Access Control Policy description "Defines access control requirements for IT systems"
control.note: Controls are security measures that mitigate risks in your ISMS (e.g., policies, procedures, technical controls).

document.optional: Add description: create document Security Policy description "Organization-wide information security policy"
document.note: Documents represent policies, procedures, and other ISMS documentation.

incident.optional: Add description: create incident Data Breach 2026-01-05 description "Unauthorized access to customer database"
incident.note: Incidents are security events that need to be tracked and managed in your ISMS.

scenario.optional: Add description: create scenario Ransomware Attack description "Scenario for testing ransomware response procedures"
scenario.note: Scenarios represent risk scenarios or business continuity scenarios in your ISMS.

process.optional: Add description: create process Incident Response description "Process for handling security incidents"
process.note: Processes represent business or security processes in your ISMS.
